Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male cult figure wearing wearing festival wreath headdress with lotus buds. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating and red paint on hair. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar style and headdress to Memphis example dated to the 3rd century BC (Petrie 1909, Pl.39, no.36), and an unprovenanced piece at Dresden dated to the 1st century BC (Fischer 1994, Pl.44, no.447). Other similar examples from Naukratis, now at Cambridge (NA681, NA670, NA683). Fischer, J. 1994. ‘Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen’. Tübingen: Wasmuth. Petrie, W.M.F. 1909. Memphis volume I. London: School of Archaeology in Egypt.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.538) (Phase 1)
